W. I.1st October, 1958 S2CR2YPROROGATION speech my Lords and Members of the House of commons. My Dear Husband and I derived great pleasure from our visit to the Netherlands in April.2. I was pleased to welcome the President of Italy andSignora Gronchi, and the President of the Federal Republic of Germanyto this country.3. I rejoice that the good relations between this country and theU. S. A. are growing ever closer. My Government welcome the agreement concluded with the Government of the United States for co-operation onthe use of atomic energy for purposes of mutual defence.4. My Government have continued to support the constructive workof the United Nations Organisation. They have maintained their efforts to bring about further progress towards disarmament.5. My Government have continued to play their full part in theNorth Atlantic Treaty Organisation and the other regional pacts to whichthey belong.6. In response to an appeal by the Jordanian Government certain of My forces were despatched to Amman to preserve the territorial integrity and political independence of the country. A few days earlier,United States forces had landed in the Lebanon in response to a similarappeal from the Lebanese President and My Government had fully supported this action. They made it clear to the United Nations thatBritish forces would be withdrawn from Jordan either at the request ofthe legitimate Government or when satisfactory arrangements to preserveJordanian independence had been made under United Nations auspices.7. My Government took part in the Conference at Geneva on the law of the Sea and have signed the resulting Conventions on the regime of thehigh seas, the territorial sea, the continental shelf and fishery conservation. They have continued their efforts to negotiate a settlement with Icelandabout fishery limits and are meanwhile affording protection to british vessels engaged in their traditional fisheries in the high seas aroundIceland^/ jji reference later to International Court^/8. The enthusiastic welcome which My Dear Mother received duringher recent visit to Australia and New Zealand has been a great joy to Me.In January, My Dear Sister represented Me at the Inauguration inTrinidad of the Legislature of the new Federation of the West Indies and she subsequently visited Guiana and British Honduras. More recentlyshe has visited Canada. I was happy to hear from her of the warmthand loyalty with which she was greeted everywhere.9. My Government took part in the Commonwealth Trade andEconomic Conference at Montreal. This meeting emphasised the importance which the countries of the Commonwealth attach to ensuring that they play their full role in measures directed towards the expansion of the world economy and the improvement of living standards.-1-311 10. The cordial reception given to My Prime Minister during hisduring his tour of India, Pakistan, Ceylon, Singapore, New Zealand and australia afforded me great satisfaction. The many discussions whichhe had with statesmen in these countries served to strengthen stillfurther the ties of friendship within the Commonwealth.11. Jj? Cyprus, including reference to Armed Forces./12. During the year an Act was passed granting a new constitution to Singapore under the title of the State of Singapore and extending thestatus of Commonwealth citizenship to the recently created Singaporecitizenship.13. An Order in Council has been made providing for an all-AfricanExecutive Council in Sierra Leone under the presidency of the Governor.Members of the House of Commons14. I thank you for the provision which you have made for the public services.My Lords and Members of the House of Commons15. The constant endeavour of My Ministers to strengthen the economyhas improved our balance of payments and fortified our reserves, while maintaining a high level of employment for My People and securinggreater stability in the value of their money. Additional legislation hasbeen enacted with a view to sustaining employment in particular areas.16. Measures have been taken to remove controls over the supplyand retail prices of coal and over iron and steel scrap prices; to reviseand codify the law relating to import duties; and to establish aConservancy Board at Milford Haven.17. My Government have continued to support home agriculture inaccordance with the long-term assurances given to the industry, and have provided further assistance for the fishing industry. Legislation has been passed to repeal the disciplinary powers of the State over owners andoccupiers of agricultural land and to modify the law relating to securityof tenure and the arbitration of rents on tenanted farms. An Act has been passed to facilitate the drainage of agricultural land in Scotland. Freshprovision has been made with respect to the licensing and regulation ofslaughterhouses in England and Wales.18. Acts have been passed to bring to an end the emergency powersdealing with land used for defence purposes and opencast coal productionand to replace them, so far as necessary, with more limited permanentpowers. The emergency legislation concerning supplies of water in timeof drought has also been replaced.19. In accordance with the resolve of My Ministers to improve the institutions of government, machinery has been established by statute forre-organising local government in England and Wales.-2-S EC RET 20. Changes have also been made in the rating system and in thesystem of Exchequer grants to local authorities throughout Great Britain.21. A measure has been passed to permit the creation of lifePeerages for men and women, carrying the right to sit and vote in theHouse of Lords.22. Improvements have been made in the law relating to the re-distribution of seats in the House of Commons.23. Measures have been taken to give effect to the majority of therecommendations of the Committee on Administrative Tribunals and enquiries.24. The social welfare of My People has continued to be the special care of My Government. War pensions and retirement pensions havebeen raised; rates of benefit under the National Insurance and industrial injuries Scheme have been increased; and improvements have been made inthe scales of National Assistance.25. An .rt.ct has also been passed to improve the arrangements for theindustrial rehabilitation, training and resettlement of disabled persons.26. An Act has been passed to alleviate possible hardship to tenantswho might otherwise be faced with immediate loss of possession of certaindwelling-houses released from control.27. The Maintenance Orders Act will achieve a useful measure of social reform in England and Wales by facilitating the enforcement ofmaintenance orders while at the same time reducing the number of mencommitted to prison in default of payment.28. Important reforms affecting the welfare of children are being effected by an Act amending the law of adoption and making fresh provisionfor the supervision of those who take children-into their care for payment.My Lords and Members of the House of Commons29. I pray that the blessing of Almighty God may attend you.
